item.title: By: Lev Reyzin
item.dc:creator: Lev Reyzin
item.description: Another puzzle is why the strategy above doesn't work for Go.
item.content:encoded: Another puzzle is why the strategy above doesn’t work for Go.

item.title: By: Arthur B.
item.dc:creator: Arthur B.
item.description: The first player should place a pawn dead in the center, after that, place a pawn which is center symmetric with the opponent's last move, it's always possible because the board remains symmetric at all time, and the center symmetric position can't overlap because the disc in the center has been taken already.
item.content:encoded: The first player should place a pawn dead in the center, after that, place a pawn which is center symmetric with the opponent’s last move, it’s always possible because the board remains symmetric at all time, and the center symmetric position can’t overlap because the disc in the center has been taken already.

item.title: By: dreeves
item.dc:creator: dreeves
item.description:
(I just temporarily censored a comment that was too much of a spoiler for the puzzle. Most of our puzzles here are variants of things we've heard before. We just try to make them ungooglable (and add twists). So no spoiling it by mapping it back to a potentially googlable form!)
[I uncensored it now that we got a solution.]
item.content:encoded:
(I just temporarily censored a comment that was too much of a spoiler for the puzzle. Most of our puzzles here are variants of things we’ve heard before. We just try to make them ungooglable (and add twists). So no spoiling it by mapping it back to a potentially googlable form!)

[I uncensored it now that we got a solution.]

item.title: By: Kevin Canini
item.dc:creator: Kevin Canini
item.description: Regarding the bonus puzzle, I heard this one many years ago, but using a big round table instead of a chessboard, and quarters instead of pawns. The solution I was given requires the ability to make extremely precise measurements of the table and the coins.
item.content:encoded: Regarding the bonus puzzle, I heard this one many years ago, but using a big round table instead of a chessboard, and quarters instead of pawns. The solution I was given requires the ability to make extremely precise measurements of the table and the coins.
